Bell

I haven't posted in quite some time, but I still lurk occasionally. Not much has changed. :)
 
 Someone on another forum I read had an abortion last week, and she typed up her account of what happened. I just want people to read it. Take it as you will.
 
 "We arrived yesterday early but there were already protesters there. I was extremely annoyed by their presence, presumptions, and gall. One of them, a fat woman in her 30s, brought her children with her, all 6 of them, and they ran toward us when we got out of the car. They were all young but it seemed like some of them should have been in school. They danced around my husband and I shouting, "mommy, mommy, don't kill me mommy. Mommy, i'm your baby, i'm your son. Mommy i'm your daughter. Mommy i'm your baby boy. Mommy i'm your baby girl. Mommy let me live. Mommy I love you already. Mommy my heart is beating so strong. Mommy you'll braid my hair one day, it's just like yours. Mommy you'll teach me to read and write. Mommy i'm going to take care of you when you get old. Mommy i'll always love you." 
 
 the oldest boy in the group, who was probably 8 or 9, ran up to my husband and said, "dad, don't let her do it! Daddy, don't you want me? Dad, don't you love me? Dad, we'll play baseball in the backyard together, just you me. Dad, don't you want to teach me to ride a bike? Daddy i'm going to be a doctor, you'll be so proud of me. Daddy don't let her kill me. Daddy I have your eyes already. Daddy we'll watch football together." 
 
 they were very vicious little brats and they kept looking back towards the fat woman who kept smiling and encouraging them on. We finally wound around them and then were in the midst of all of the protesters before we could safely cross the street and they were even worse than the coached children. 
 
 An older fat man waved a very wrinkled $50 in my face and said, "there's more where this comes from if you don't murder your baby. You need help with the bills, we can help you just don't go in there today. You need anything else we can get it for you just don't murder your innocent baby." 
 
 when I continued walking an old woman, probably around the age of my grandmother, came up and began speaking very gently, "you know you don't want to kill your baby, that baby needs you honey. You're his mother." 
 
 but then when I kept walking down the sidewalk toward the crosswalk she began to get more irate and in my face. She started screaming, "you're his mommy, you're supposed to protect him from everything, from harm, from death! You're supposed to give your life for him! How can you be so selfish?! That baby didn't ask for you to spread your legs and now you're going to mu-der him because it's inconvenient for you! This life is not for your comfort and pleasure but for the lord's! Mu-derer!!!!!" 
 
 when she screamed that, the rest of the protesters rushed around me and I was afraid that they would do something or hold me back or hurt my husband or myself. They were all screaming at once because I kept trying to walk past them and ignore them. It was very, very hard to ignore the things that they were saying and if a volunteer escort hadn't come up to help us, my husband would have lost it and gotten into a fight. 
 
 I would have never thought it was possible for someone my grandmother's age to scream such profanity at me. I'm still in shock about that. That, more than anything else, bothered me deeply. That people are so concerned about my body that they would block my path on a busy street and call me all manner of profane things. That they think it's any of their business. That they think they have the right to do it. That anyone else thinks this behavior is acceptable and that women going to a health center must tolerate it is beyond me. I still can't get over that. I'm very angry about it. 
 
 When we finally did get into the health center, the staff was so incredibly wonderful, respectful, compassionate, and answered all of my questions. I couldn't stop telling them "thank you, thank you, thank you." I said it to everyone. The front desk people, security, volunteers, doctor, nurses, secretaries, everyon. I'm thinking of sending them some baked goods from this wonderful company that sends big, packaged goodies. I couldn't be more thankful of them and for them and for what they did for me. 
 
 When we left, the disgusting protesters tried to put pamphlets into my hands and bag. They tried to talk to me about getting after abortion counseling, as if i'd ever go to them for anything, ever, after they put me through all of that. And I rather don't think I need it. I feel fine about the abortion, good in fact. And I doubt that they would be encouraged by hearing me say what a great abortion I had. I got the distinct impression that they wanted me to feel horrible about it so that they feel justified in treating me like #### before I got into the building. They'll get no justification from me. 
 
 Why do we put up with this? It was hard enough to come to this decision in the first place without walking through all of that and having no other option but to take it, walk through it. I still hear their voices and see their faces. If I ever see their faces again, I may have to slap some sense into them. It was unneccessary and beyond rude to a place where I don't think there is a word in the english language to define it. I'm still enfuriated about them, the way I was treated by them."

Yep, it's really sad the lengths that they'll go to. I really wonder about the mental stability of such people, and wonder if they really think they are getting their "brownie points" for heaven by their disgusting and hateful behaviour.

 one thing did spark my interest, and it is said often, why is it a "hard decision" if you are pro-choice? Is it hard because you don't know if you want a baby around or not? Couldn't this decision be just as hard before being pregnant? Even so, why link it to going to an abortion clinic? You hear "It was hard enough to come to this decision in the first place" but how is going through some protestors making this decision harder? 
 
 No one would admit to this but it is statements like "It was hard enough to come to this decision in the first place" that make me believe that someone realizes it is wrong and the struggle that makes it hard is whether or not to do the right thing or do they thing that would benefit you the most. And in that case, I agree...that can be a tough decision.

 I would venture to guess that, for most women, the reason that the decision is hard is that the embryo/fetus that is being aborted will most likely grow into a full-fledged person if it is allowed to continue and they are cutting that short. That potential is very important to some women and less so to others and the farther along in the pregnancy it has developed, the more that potential comes to mind. The abortion decision is the WEIGHING of various factors - meaning weighing of factors for abortion (ex. cannot support a new child, too young to have one, or even rape or incest) vs factors against abortion (ex. the potential of that embryo/fetus to grow into a person, the disapproval of more conservative members of friends and family). For some women, they don't care at all about that potential or other anti-abortion arguements, so the decision is easy for them. For other women, the anti-abortion arguements do weigh heavily but the pro-abortion reasons weigh more heavily, so their decision is a hard one.

 As an adoptive parent, I have a question for you. How do you feel about open adoptions? I think there are a lot situations where the parents are too young to parent, but do not have it in themselves to go through a pregnancy and then never see that baby again - and then we end up with abortions or really bad parenting situations. I believe more open adoption might help with this, but wonder how open adoptive parents would be to it. What is your opinion on the matter?
Good question. Our adoption was closed and went through a church supported agency. My son has always known he was adopted and was told that his birth mother placed him with us because she loved him. He accepted that, had a normal childhood and has shown no interest in seeking her out (we would have no problem with that). I am sure that there are many happy success stories from open adoptions, but my personal choice would still be closed. 
 My son is on his way here to drop off my grandson for a visit. He will smile and say "Hi, Dad" and I will again be grateful for that faithful decision made over 40 years ago.

But Dr's had examples of aborted fetuses at every stage of development so these abortion clinics knew very well exactly how developed a 12 week old fetus is. They blatantly and purposely lied to get that abortion done.
 
 My question is why !?!?!?!?!? If abortions are a pure and simple public service to aid women with unwanted pregnancies, then why lie, deceive, and manipulate women into getting them ? Are they on commission or something ? Why is this one medical procedure treated so differently that other medical procedures which are done to extend and protect life where as abortion is done to end life and will only be refused to a woman if it will endanger her life. Why the contradictions and inconsistencies based on the medical norms we otherwise rely on in the Medical Profession ?
 
 I also wasn't saved then and didn't understand that life does begin at conception as I realized when I became a believer. That too changed my opinion about abortion.

I think that people screaming "murderer" and otherwise harassing women walking into an abortion providing clinic do so primarily to inflate their own sense of importance. "Here I am on the frontlines of a Life And Death Issue. I may save a life and therefore impart greater meaning to my own". Still I support their right to do so, and from my perspective having had an abortion in 1972, experiencing a hard time walking into a clinic to have an abortion is a relatively small price to pay for the ability to do so safely and legally. 
 
 6 weeks before Roe v Wade, my abortion actually was safe and legal but that was not assured back then. I was lucky to be on a college campus with a newspaper that published a contact number, lucky to be only one state away from a clinic operating temporarily due to a court injunction, and lucky to be able to borrow the money from a friend for the abortion and bus fare to get there. I went alone and was nervous about what to expect from the whole experience, not least of which was the vastly intimidating experience at 18 of having to change busses in Chicago in the middle of the night! 
 
 The clinic was in temporary office space in an old building in downtown Milwaukee, run by a group of feminist volunteers who nevertheless provided a well managed, professional experience. But I was well aware it could have been much different. Like women all over the world who currently drink questionable concoctions or put themselves in the hands of shady characters risking their lives, criminal prosecution and infertility, or attempt to self-abort with knitting needles or the like, I felt like I would have done nearly anything  to not be pregnant, to not have a baby. 
 
 There was a famous photo published by Ms. magazine back then of a woman on her knees, naked and slumped forward, found dead on a towel on the floor of a motel room. The picture was shot from the back, in black and white, her buttocks pale and vulnerable with a big pool of blood visible between her legs. I could have been here; I was her. 
 
 Walk a 5 minute gauntlet of screaming protestors? Piece of cake. 
 
 JL

 You said in a previous post "2 short months after ROE V WADE was passed my girl friend got pregnant. We were barely 21 years old."
 
 19, 21. Pretty important milestones at that age, coupled with an abortion; how could you not know how old you were? Especially in 1973, when the draft had been also just very recently abolished. I first voted in 1972, at 18. How 'bout you? That was a heady experience, since the law had just changed to allow 18 year olds to vote. "Old enough to get drafted and die in Viet Nam, old enough to vote!" was the argument. 19. 21. Easily mistaken? Hard to remember? No way. Not in 1973. 
 
 And your "secret agenda" is also just so much hokum. Abortion is not a multi-billion dollar industry as you previous stated. So says National Right to Life: At an average cost of $372, the abortion business is a $400 million a year industry. 
 
 And at an average cost of $372, the cost has barely increased in 30 years! About how many medical procedures can we say that? And of course, the cost increases with the complexity of the procedure, which is also par for the course in the medical field. 
 
 But then I understand that you have a mythology going here. Abortion providers are the big bad wolf preying on innocent teenagers who are so naive they may as well be 6th graders apparently, all so they can line their pockets with bloody carcasses and gold! 
 
 Tell me something, Archangel, given that you believe abortion is murdering children, and given your own alleged complicity in said act in the past, what do you think is a fitting punishment for child murder? And have you paid this price to society? 
 
 Of course, I jest. No one really thinks that abortion is "child murder". This is just rhetoric. To paraphrase something Michael Kinsley once said in an editorial following the murder of an abortion provider, if you really believe that 1 million plus children are being slaughtered every year, shouldn't more of you being killing abortion providers? Shouldn't you be doing more to prevent annual mass murder of children?? 
 
 Shouldn't those of you who have availed yourselves of the opportunity won by others to have a safe and legal abortion at least rent some garments and pillory yourself in the public square, offer a pound of flesh or something for your crime of "child murder"? After all, contrition and finding Christ isn't enough for some of those people on Death Row, is it? They must fry for their crime! How 'bout you? Are you ready to at least spend, oh, say, 15-20 in the local prison for your part in child murder? 
 
 No, of course not. It's just rhetoric. (Unfortunate rhetoric, when people such as your former girlfriend believe it.)

It in no way caused me to consider preventing me from welcoming my own into the world. My memories consist of many pee and poop and pukey episodes. But my memory is flooded with my babies looking me in the eye, as they lay on my chest saying, "I luv loo dally". And many many more episodes I would love to share and relive. They were both un-planned, they were both a financial burden, they both tested my patience, they both are the greatest blessings a human could ever hope for. I wish we would have had many more.
gman

1. So, how many kids do you have?
 
 2. And, do you know their names? What they like to do?
 
 3. It doesn't sound like you've been much of a dad if all you did is providing for them. Did you watch TV sports the rest of the time?

 
 1. Two
 2. My wife and "I" named them. 
 Do I know what they like to do? Wow, you surely have had a terrible life. 
 I know everything about my kids. What their favorite colors are. What bands they like. How much money they have in the bank. 
 3. I was and am a great dad and a great granddad. 
 I did do a lot of providing. And never minded blowing my money on youngin's. 
 I taught them how to drive on country roads in Kansas and my boy would fetch the truck when I needed to drag a deer out of the woods at 10 years old. He loved it, I loved it. My girl could drive t 10 too. Went to college on a volleyball scholarship. Now teaches school and raises her 3 babies. Life is good. When we get the chance.
Winston Smith

So, how many kids do you have?
 
 And, do you know their names? What they like to do?
 
 It doesn't sound like you've been much of a dad if all you did is providing for them. Did you watch TV sports the rest of the time?

 
 so watching TV sports = bad daddy?
 
 do you let your boyfriend/girlfriend or husband watch TV sports or only feminist approved TV channels?
simone
Winston, watching American TV is evillllllllllllllllll! And don't you ever forget it!
jitobear

Gman - not every story matches yours. Nor does every family. Now try these - your pregnant and your broke, or alone, or in an abusive relationship, or 13, or you can't work and your a single mom with two kids, or you'll lose your scholorship and never be able to afford an education. 
 
 All the condemnation in the workd won't fix these very real problems.
Winston Smith

Winston, watching American TV is evillllllllllllllllll! And don't you ever forget it!

 
 Only if Dubya is on the screen
gman

Gman - not every story matches yours. Nor does every family. Now try these - your pregnant and your broke, or alone, or in an abusive relationship, or 13, or you can't work and your a single mom with two kids, or you'll lose your scholorship and never be able to afford an education. 
 
 All the condemnation in the workd won't fix these very real problems.

 
 If you're broke, you got no business gettin' it on. Abortions cost money. 
 If you're pregnant, you weren't alone. 
 Fathers of abused women should punish abusers of their daughters. 
 13? Your father needs his stupid XXX kicked. So do you. 
 Get a court appointed lawyer, go after the scum that made the babies. take their money. 
 Making excuses for these hardships won't solve them either. 
 Condemnation is a form of communication that has the ability to make some realize that stupidity can have a serious price. Giving help to the downtrodden does not have to consist of killing the most innocent in the situation.
 
 By the way, I now that not all lives are like mine. I was just answering some questions. Asked merely in the hope of proving a point.
jitobear

If you're broke, you got no business gettin' it on. Abortions cost money. 

 
 Maybe so, but hind sight is 20/20 and abortion costs signifigantly less than pregnancy or parenting.
 
 
If you're pregnant, you weren't alone.

 
 That doesn't mean squat. Plenty of men walk.
 
 
Fathers of abused women should punish abusers of their daughters. 
 13? Your father needs his stupid XXX kicked. So do you.

 
 You assume dad is around or cares.
 
 
Get a court appointed lawyer, go after the scum that made the babies. take their money. 

 
 You assume these men can be found or have money.
 
 
Making excuses for these hardships won't solve them either. 

 
 Whose making excuses? I am citing very real issues.
 
 
Condemnation is a form of communication that has the ability to make some realize that stupidity can have a serious price. 

 
 Using pregnancy and children as a punitive measure. Golly gee - don't you just love babies.
 
 
Giving help to the downtrodden does not have to consist of killing the most innocent in the situation.

 
 I agree, but not enough help exists and many of these very real issues are written off as "convenience matters" by lifers.
 
 
By the way, I now that not all lives are like mine. I was just answering some questions. Asked merely in the hope of proving a point.

 
 In the end, my point is that addressing pregnant women's needs will go miles further in reducing abortion than condemnation will.
Winston Smith

It appears to me that gman or is it (he-man?) can not put himself in the shoes of the disadvantaged and therefore nonchalantly he dismisses their plight. On the other hand it is true that the innocent pay the price. And again, what the innocent grow up to do the same her mother has done?
 I think the sisters should care more about correcting the social conditions which lead to unwanted pregnancies rather than telling the poor girls: " Have an abortion it is your right"
jitobear

I think the sisters should care more about correcting the social conditions which lead to unwanted pregnancies rather than telling the poor girls: " Have an abortion it is your right"

 
 In the end - safe abortions should be a right - but I do believe that we all, on both sides of the issue, could do miles more in addressing what leads to unwanted pregnancies and addressing the issues of pregnant women.
gman

1. Maybe so, but hind sight is 20/20 and abortion costs signifigantly less than pregnancy or parenting.
 2. That doesn't mean squat. Plenty of men walk.
 3. You assume dad is around or cares.
 4. You assume these men can be found or have money.
 5. Whose making excuses? I am citing very real issues.
 6. Using pregnancy and children as a punitive measure. Golly gee - don't you just love babies.
 7. I agree, but not enough help exists and many of these very real issues are written off as "convenience matters" by lifers.
 8. In the end, my point is that addressing pregnant women's needs will go miles further in reducing abortion than condemnation will.

 
 1. You are correct about 20/20. You are wrong about the cost. The cost is everything to the life lost. The only innocent in the formula. 
 2. You're right on this too. More effort needs to be put into holding men accountable. Starting at home. Where parents educate their sons on respecting women and doing what is right.
 3. I understand that yours is the reality. I understand that instead of dealing with these issues at the cost of a child's life is wrong. More emphasis by the powers that be need to focus on responsibility by all parties. This is not an easy task, but a worthy task. 
 I feel the need to define the "powers that be". 
 Parents, schools, Hollywood, MTV, Planned Parenthood, friends and family. It would take a concerted effort from all the those mentioned, but, together, they could help people's frame of mind concerning the results of their actions. 
 4. They can not be without serious effort from our legal system.
 5. Yes, you are citing real issues and then making the excuses for the wrong actions.
 6. Making statements that hold people responsible for their actions is hardly a statement that I don't love them. Maintaining standards is an act of love versus neglect from not considering the results of peoples actions. 
 7. That help could develop if people put as much effort into it as they do defending the right to abort. 
 8. Well put.
gman

It appears to me that gman or is it (he-man?) can not put himself in the shoes of the disadvantaged and therefore nonchalantly he dismisses their plight. On the other hand it is true that the innocent pay the price. And again, what the innocent grow up to do the same her mother has done?
 I think the sisters should care more about correcting the social conditions which lead to unwanted pregnancies rather than telling the poor girls: " Have an abortion it is your right"

 
 Naturally a personal attack would be called for when you don't read all that is written. I have no need to "put myself in anyone's shoes". I not only support help for the downtrodden, I demand it. I also demand personal responsibility from those who create these situations. 
 The statements I have made along with my condemnation of irresponsibility add up to exactly your last paragraph.
jitobear

2. You're right on this too. More effort needs to be put into holding men accountable. Starting at home. Where parents educate their sons on respecting women and doing what is right.

3. I understand that yours is the reality. I understand that instead of dealing with these issues at the cost of a child's life is wrong. More emphasis by the powers that be need to focus on responsibility by all parties. This is not an easy task, but a worthy task. 
 I feel the need to define the "powers that be". 
 Parents, schools, Hollywood, MTV, Planned Parenthood, friends and family. It would take a concerted effort from all the those mentioned, but, together, they could help people's frame of mind concerning the results of their actions.

 
 And everyone on both sides of this issue.
 
 
4. They can not be without serious effort from our legal system.

5. Yes, you are citing real issues and then making the excuses for the wrong actions.

 
 Sometimes excuses are valid. 
 
 
6. Making statements that hold people responsible for their actions is hardly a statement that I don't love them. Maintaining standards is an act of love versus neglect from not considering the results of peoples actions. 

 
 Before you claim your action is loving you need to realize that your expectation does not necesarily equate to their ability.
 
 
7. That help could develop if people put as much effort into it as they do defending the right to abort. 

 
 And how about the energy put into trying to ban it?

Naturally a personal attack would be called for when you don't read all that is written. I have no need to "put myself in anyone's shoes". I not only support help for the downtrodden, I demand it. I also demand personal responsibility from those who create these situations. 
 The statements I have made along with my condemnation of irresponsibility add up to exactly your last paragraph.

 Even if they do not, they learn the price of indulging without forethought. Let them pay the price. Not the innocent result of "their" action.
